title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May BBC Question Time European Union
story: During her first appearance on the BBC panel show, Theresa May suggested the European elections in 1999 meant the British people were already growing frustrated with the EU.Mrs May claimed the Conservative Party won the most amount of seats at the election because they campaigned on a clear message they did not want to be &ldquorun by Europe.She said: &ldquoI actually find this argument a little strange. It&rsquos a bit like someone who manufactures cars saying &lsquowell nobody is buying our cars because they like them so much&rsquo.&ldquoThis idea from the Government that because everyone is happy with them they are not going to go out and vote for their members of the European Parliament.                May dealt huge blow as Tory MP demands LEADERSHIP ELECTION&ldquoI think there are a variety of reasons why people didn&rsquot go out and vote.&ldquoI think one of the reasons was that it was a proportional representation system and certainly I found people saying to me that they were unhappy about the fact they couldn&rsquot vote for a particular candidate and had to vote for a party.&ldquoDespite the leaflet that came through, there wasn&rsquot an explain lot done to explain that electoral system to people. I happen to not support that electoral system, I believe in actually being able to vote for a candidate who is then going to represent you.&ldquoCertainly I found a lot of people were concerned about not having a candidate they could vote for.She added: &ldquoBut also the two other parties ran, well they didn&rsquot really run campaigns at all for the European election.&ldquoI think we were the only party that went out with a clear message to people that was based on issues related to Europe. We wanted to be in Europe, not run by Europe.&ldquoI think the results of the European elections overwhelmingly showed that was the opinion of the mainstream of the British public.In response&nbsphost,&nbspDavid Dimbleby pointed out the party had only achieved &ldquoeight&nbsppercent&nbspof the total electorate.Mrs May replied: &ldquoMore of those who went out and voted, voted Conservative than voted anything else.Brexit news: In 1999 Theresa May claimed Tories success in elections was during to their EU message (Image: BBC&bull)The Conservative Party won 36 seats at the 1999 European elections, compared to the Labour Party who won 29 seats.The Liberal Democrats won 10 seats with the UK Independence Party winning three seats.The election was held on 10 June 1999 and was the first European election to be held in the UK where the whole country used proportional representation. Turnout for the election was only 24&nbsppercent.Tweeting the archive video, the BBC Question Time twitter account added: &ldquoTheresa May made her first appearance and rejected the suggestion that a low turnout at the European Parliament elections (24percent) meant the public were satisfied with the status quo.During her speech at the Conservative Party conference on Wednesday, Mrs May she wanted a good Brexit agreement but warned the EU Britain isn't afraid to leave with no deal if we had to.She said: Don&rsquot let anyone tell you we don&rsquot have what it takes. We have everything we need to succeed.

story: Airbus is quite capable of building a rival to Galileo, says Andrew Stroomer (Image: )Andrew Stroomer, business development director with Airbus Defence and Space has no doubt doubt his team of experts has the know-how to build a stand-alone satellite navigation system out of a facility which, together with other UK sites in Portsmouth and Newport in Wales, currently builds an impressive 25 percent of the world&rsquos telecommunications satellites.And he also emphasised that he &ldquosaw no reason why the cutting edge Hertfordshire facility would be going anywhere after Brexit - despite warnings by the parent company about the impact of leaving the EU.The site is currently home to pioneering projects including development of the ExoMars rover, a vehicle which will be capable of drilling down into the Red Planet to look for evidence of life, as well as the Solar Orbiter, a mission due to launch in 2020 which will perform close observations of the Sun.And Mr Stroomer believes the accumulated expertise leaves Airbus &ndash&nbspand the UK &ndash well-placed.                Galileo FURY: Greg Clark says EU&rsquos plan to block UK is an &lsquoinsult'                 MP warns EU over threat to expel UK from Galileo programmeHe told Express: &ldquoWe would like Galileo to continue with the participation of the UK.&ldquoBut if you look at Galileo, the UK has contributed some of the most complicated parts of that.&ldquoWe don&rsquot do everything &ndash&nbspbut we do enough to show we are capable of building such a system for the UK.&ldquoFrom an industry point of view, we have the capability.The UK faces exclusion from Galileo after Brexit (Image: )&ldquoThere would not be a conflict of interest.&ldquoIt would mean working with the UK government as a customer.Mr Stroomer remained confident the cutting edge Hertfordshire facilities, where 1500 people are employed, would continuing to operate after the UK quits the EU next year.He explained: &ldquoThere&rsquos no reason why our work with the ESA and telecommunications satellites should not continue as they are.                Tory MEP confident UK will create BETTER Commonwealth Galileo systemGraham Turnock accused the EU of inflexibility over Galileo (Image: BBC)&ldquoThis is our flagship manufacturing site and it is difficult to imagine moving from here.He also pointed out that Airbus was also heavily involved in numerous aspects of the Copernicus Earth observation programme, which provides accurate, timely and easily accessible information to improve the management of the environment, understand and mitigate the effects of climate change and ensure civil security, and would continue to be so for the foreseeable future.Mr Stroomer&rsquos comments echo those of Graham Turnock, head of the UK Space Agency, who last month accused the European Commission of an &ldquoinflexible approach over plans to freeze the UK out of Galileo, despite the fact that British taxpayers have so far paid an estimated &pound1billion towards to the &pound8.5billion costs of the project.Mr Turnock told the BBC&rsquos Hard Talk current affairs programme: &ldquoWe&rsquove supplied about 20 percent of the kit and capability going into the project.At the moment the negotiations are not showing sufficient flexibility on the side of the European Commission to enable us to continue to participate.&ldquoWe think it&rsquos a pity the European Commission is taking the position that it is.&ldquoIf we want to build our own system now we&rsquod benefit from a lot of learning and we have a simpler project to deliver because it would not be a project that is being managed by 28 separate member states.&ldquoThere&rsquos no reason why we shouldn&rsquot do. It&rsquos perfectly within our capability on the basis of the initial analysis we have made.

Whereas, further north and west we will see some spells of sunshine and across the board a much cooler feel to the weather.Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden warned that milder, settled conditions forecast over the coming days could eventually give way to a bombardment of winter storms.He said: &ldquoA final burst of summer could be in the offing around the middle of next week however the first snow of the season will not be too far behind.&ldquoAt least one or two major low-pressure systems will attempt to cause havoc on our weather patterns within this period, and this is most likely from mid-month onwards.&ldquoWe also expect at least one of these low-pressure systems to arrive under a colder airmass to the north of the country during the final third of October, and it is within this period that we could see the first significant snow of the season across higher ground in parts of Scotland and the north.Tropical storm Leslie is also currently hurtling across the Atlantic and threatening to trigger a fortnight-long storm in the UK next week.Furious winds, torrential rain and wintry downpours could plague the nation until the end of October, sparking warnings of an early winter freeze.The Met Office has warned if the storm does end up coming towards Britain its impact will be felt towards the end of next week.Met Office chief meteorologist Andy Page said: &ldquoLeslie will likely strengthen to a hurricane as it moves over warmer waters with large swells affecting Bermuda and east coast of the United States and the Caribbean.&ldquoIt is likely to gradually weaken after this and move eastwards across the North Atlantic.&ldquoSome models suggest Leslie will track south of the UK while others suggest it may move close to the UK by the end of next week.

title: EU news Italy Matteo Salvini Jean Claude Juncker economy budget debate latest Di Maio
story: Italy's deputy leader Matteo Salvini slapped down the Eurocrat after Mr Juncker suggesting the eurosceptic Italian Government could catapult the country into a Greece-like economic crisis.&nbspJean-Claude Juncker said the European Union must do everything to avoid a new financial slump in the bloc after Italy put forward plans for a 2.4 percent deficit increase in its 2019 budget.But Mr Salvini did not let the thinly-veiled threat slide, hitting back on La7 show Tagad&agrave on Tuesday: I only speak to sober people who don&rsquot make unrealistic comparisons.In such a big family there are no first class or second class children. If someone in Brussels babbles because they regret the loss of a precarious and fearful Italy &ndash maybe to make business at a lower price using spread and the markets to scare people &ndash they found the wrong Minister and the wrong Government.                Italy&rsquos deputy chief says Merkel and Macron want Rome to FALLMr Salvini had previously urged the EU Commissioner to drink two glasses of water before speaking or face demands for compensation from the Italian Government.&nbspHe continued: The President of the European Commission, comparing Italy to Greece, is making the spread gap go insane. He could have spared us that.Before opening his mouth, he should drink two glasses of water and stop spreading inexistent threats. Or we will ask for compensation.The eurosceptic politician appeared to echo similar digs at the European Commissioner from former Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson.&nbspEU news: Italian deputy PM Salvini said he only spoke to  (Image: LA REPUBBLICA&bullEPTV)Speaking at the Tory Party conference on Tuesday, Mr Johnson said: I will reveal that I have one overriding anxiety about the current political scene, both domestic and international.It isn&rsquot global warming or terrorism or Rouhani&rsquos Iran or Putin&rsquos Russia &ndash real though all those challenges are. It&rsquos not the negotiating tactics of Jean-Claude Juncker &ndash before or after lunch.In July, world leaders were filmed helping hold up Mr Juncker after stumbling and losing his balance ahead of a NATO dinner.The EU Commission boss has previously blamed the unsteadiness on sciatica, which can cause numbness or weakness of the legs.Speaking after the event, European Commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas confirmed&nbspMr&nbspJuncker had suffered from a particularly painful attack of sciatica which was &ldquoaccompanied with cramps.When asked by a reporter if Mr Juncker was drunk, Mr Schinas said it is more than tasteless that some press tried to make insulting headlines by exploiting President Juncker's pain.European Commission spokesman Alexander Winterstein told Express: &ldquoThe President's respect and, indeed, affection for Italy and the Italian people is well known.&ldquoAs far as the draft budget is concerned, the Commission will assess it once it is submitted, based on the rules and procedures in place &ndash as always.Riding the wave of discontent with the EU, Italy's other deputy Prime Minister Luigi Di Maio warned the Government won't stop despite threats from Brussels.Mr&nbspDi Maio said: The EU threatens us but we won&rsquot stop. We are most definitely concerned about the spread but we have a different focus.Yesterday, someone was unhappy spread hadn&rsquot reached 350 yet so in the afternoon EU Commissioners and the Commission President came out with comments to create some tension and markets are sensitive to the statements of the Commission.The Italian government is now obliged to send its draft budgetary play to Brussels by October 15, with the actual budget being published by October 20. The European Commission will then issue a response by October 22.

title: france news macron interior minister collomb resigns
story: The former interior minister earlier told France&rsquos conservative daily Le Figaro he wanted to resign so he could run as mayor of the city of Lyon in spring 2020.When asked whether he would stay on as interior minister after Mr Macron turned down his resignation on Monday, Mr Collomb said: &ldquoThe French people and the people of Lyon need clarity, so I maintain my offer to resign.&ldquoConsidering the rumours and the pressure, I don&rsquot want the fact I will be candidate somewhere tomorrow to affect the way forward for the interior ministry.Later on Tuesday, the Elys&eacutee Palace said Mr Macron had agreed to let Mr Collomb go and that Prime Minister Edouard Philippe would fill the key cabinet post until a new replacement is found.                Macron accuses Hungary of starting &lsquoWAR&rsquo in EU over migrant crisis ...                END OF THE BROMANCE? Trump &lsquogoes off&rsquo at Macron on EU trade policiesMr Collomb is the third minister to step down in two months in a major blow to Emmanuel Macron, who&rsquos administration has been marred with setbacks.Mr Macron, for his part, said it was &ldquoregrettable that Mr Collomb had been pressured into resigning, according to his entourage.Mr Collomb&rsquos refusal to abide by Mr Macron&rsquos orders were seen by critics as a bold challenge to the President&rsquos authority, coming just weeks after the 40-year-old leader was forced to replace his popular ecology minister and the sports minister.Mr Collomb announced plans to quit the government two weeks ago, saying he would resign after European elections in May 2019 in order to cause as little disruption as possible.However, opposition rivals said his looming departure undermined his legitimacy as the head of one of the most sensitive jobs in France.Mr Collomb is the third minister to step down in two months in a major blow to Emmanuel Macron (Image: )Mr Collomb had recently become critical of Mr Macron&rsquos actions, saying the government suffered from a &ldquolack of humility and branding expressions often used by the president, such as &ldquostart up nation, as out of touch with ordinary people.&ldquoVery few of us can still talk to Mr Macron, Mr Collomb allegedly told a small group of journalists over lunch last month.&ldquoSoon he won&rsquot put up with me anymore. But if we all bow down before him, he&rsquoll end up isolated.Mr Collomb&rsquos departure adds to the many woes of the centrist head of state, who is facing record low popularity ratings after just 17 months in power.His approval ratings are currently hovering at around 30 per cent, from more than 60 per cent shortly after his landslide election in May 2017.Mr Collomb&rsquos resignation has also drawn criticism from the opposition.Conservative lawmaker Eric Ciotti compared the government to a &ldquohouse of cards that is &ldquofalling apart, while far-right leader Marine Le Pen said the face-off between Mr Macron and Mr Collomb was like a &ldquocomedy sketch.

title: typhoon tracker map live kong rey hurricane walaka hurricanes pacific ocean
story: Becoming the first pair of category five equivalent typhoons to barrel through the Pacific in ten years, Hurricane Walaka and Typhoon Kong Rey are forces to be reckoned with.&nbspOn the north side of the Pacific Ocean is Hurricane Walaka, whilst Typhoon Kong Rey rages to the west.&nbspThis is the first time since 2005 that two tropical systems of this strength churned through the ocean simultaneously.&nbspYesterday, both storms had ferocious winds of over 157mph, giving the pair the equivalent power of category five hurricanes.                Second MONSTER storm joins Super Typhoon Kong-rey in Pacific StrengthDespite weakening slightly, both storms are still powerful category four hurricane equivalents.&nbspAs of the Joint Typhoon Warning Center&rsquos (JTWC) latest update, Kong-Rey has maximum sustained winds of 115mph with higher gusts of 143mph.&nbspThis is slightly weaker than Walaka, which has maximum sustained winds of 138mph with gusts of 166mph.&nbspTwo strong typhoons are blasting their way through the Pacific Ocean (Image: CIMSS)Both behemoth storm systems are creating waves that are reaching 30 feet into the air.&nbspProximity to LandKong-Rey is moving at a rate of 10mph, whilst Walaka is moving at a speed of 17mph.&nbspIn terms of proximity to land, Kong-Rey is 342 miles north of Kadena Air Base, Okinawa, Japan.                Typhoon Kong-Rey: Winds and rain set to BATTER Japan                Is Typhoon Kong-rey MORE powerful than DEADLY Typhoon Trami?Whilst Walaka is 146 miles north of Johnston Island, Hawaii.Danger to LandWalaka has triggered a high surf advisory for nearly all islands in the Hawaiian archipelago except Big Island.&nbspWaves of 12 to 16 feet are possible.&nbspHurricane Walaka is encroaching on Hawaii, triggering warnings for most of the islands (Image: CIMSS)Typhoon Kong-Rey is close to South Korea and could cause storm conditions in a few days (Image: CIMSS)The storm is far enough away that Hawaii will avoid more-direct effects.Kong-Rey is forecast to gradually weaken over the next few days, hitting South Korea as an 85 mph cyclone Saturday.There is considerable lightning activity inside the southern eyeball of Kong-Rey, so thunderstorms could be likely.The Korea Meteorological Administration predicts a 70&nbsppercent&nbspchance that Seoul will receive hurricane force winds by this weekend.

title: theresa may brave brexit vote
story: In the largest vote ever recorded in Britain, we chose to leave the Brussels racket.And as she reveals in our exclusive interview, Theresa May is determined to tell the world that we are getting out, no s, no buts.Tory Conference this week will be testy. There remain serious splits in the party over Brexit but on one thing they must be united: nothing can imperil our exit.But while the PM is right that a second referendum is for the birds, the country is constantly holding a referendum on her leadership.On domestic issues it is Labour that seems to have an answer to everything — eventhose easy solutions rely on made-up money and would be disastrous in practice.Governments cannot just promise the world in airy-fairy speeches but, faced with an Opposition full of empty promises, the Tories must be radical.They cannot just deliver watered-down versions of whatever Jeremy Corbyn has cooked up.There are plenty of brains in the Tory party. Let’s hear their ideas and a real vision of what Britain can be.IT is disgraceful that major food stores are exploiting a legal loophole to avoid showing ingredients on packaging.Teenager Natasha Ednan-Laperouse’s death should serve as a warning of how dangerous this practice is.The law states that when food is prepared onsite, ingredients labelling is not necessary. It is designed to protect small, independent stores.But our investigation today reveals large chains have not learnt from this avoidable tragedy.Pret a Manger was warned nine times about the dangers of sesame seed in its artisan baguettes and yet it continues to sell items without allergy warnings.Now Natasha’s mother Tanya has challenged the chain to lobby for a change in our labelling laws.And, hopefully, stop other parents having to suffer such a terrible loss.BON appétit, M’luds. You’re scoffing and quaffing grub and booze to the tune of £, A DAY and WE’RE footing the bill.The House of Lords, which is filled with political cronies and gloried lobbyists,represents the very worst of Whitehall’s snouts-in-the-trough culture.The sooner we have an elected House with a few handpicked specialists, the better.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: philip hammond brexit speech trevor kavanagh opinion
story: He is also writing his ­Halloween Budget on October . Nobody is hoping for voter-friendly treats.For a man in charge of our economic destiny at such a momentous time, this “stubby-pencilled accountant” has precious little to say. It seems he even remained mute at a recent Cabinet session to war-game a No-Deal Brexit — surely the Chancellor of the Exchequer’s special subject.Well-informed Spectator editor Fraser Nelson says other ministers piled in with upbeat projects but Hammond “seemed to have no ideas and kept quiet”. Spreadsheet Phil possesses either supreme self-confidence or total contempt for the .million who voted for Brexit, or both.The man who a year ago faced political death has become the most powerful figure in Theresa May’s Cabinet — perhaps including herself.She remains the figurehead. But the minister she planned to axe until her botched General Election is running the Brexit show from his Treasury eyrie.Hammond’s sympathetic image as Eeyore, a woebegone soft toy, is misleading. This man combines thin-skinned arrogance with a rare combination of political disabilities — cloth-eared, ham-fisted and leaden-footed.The grey image of bungled Budgets and barren creativity stands in vivid contrast to his outrageous Project Fear scaremongering. Mrs May certainly deserves blame for her hapless EU negotiations and the mutant Chequers plan for a Hi-HoBrexit.THE Tories have made a decent start to their conference – but they need to set their ambitions higher.Last week the Labour Party promised easy answers on everything from housing to the economy. It was a radical,utterly disastrous, vision for Britain.The Government changing tipping rules and increasing taxes on foreign property buyers is pretty small beer.Not least since the former was first announced three years ago and the latter is pretty much copied from last year’s Labour manesto.Philip Hammond — rarely mistaken for a ray of sunshine — needs to provide light at the end of the austerity tunnel.He must lay the groundwork for entrepreneurs to thrive in a newly liberated, unapologetically free market economy.And he should challenge business to work with him, too. The self-appointed “voices of British business”, iniably dominated by large corporate interests, push every day for more and more Brexit concessions.Yet as last week showed, Labour’s unreconstructed Marxism is a far more serious threat to future prosperity than any kind of Brexit.It’s time for big businesses to play their part in building a better Britain, rather than refighting a referendum which was as much a vote against them as the political establishment.Eeyore Hammond must encourage them to invest in Britain’s future.She survived last year’s election catastrophe only because Remainers feared a true Brexiteer such as Boris Johnson might replace her.Hammond has since deployed his Treasury reach to capitalise on her weakness and box us into BRINO — Brexit In Name Only. Mrs May is the willing captive of passionate Remainers in Downing Street, Whitehall, the Cabinet Office and, crucially, the all-powerful Treasury.Since the departure of close aide Nick Timothy, there is nobody within earshot who voted Brexit — including Mrs May. Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, like his predecessor David Davis, has virtually no say in negotiations.Hammond now calls the shots, backed by panic-stirring Business Secretary Greg Clark and Europhile Cabinet Office minister David Lidington.Brexiteers fear this Unholy Trinity is ready for more concessions over issues including migration, EU benefits and Britain’s vital financial services industry.Never forget, it was Hammond who blocked all spending and therefore all serious preparation for No Deal, a prospect now apparently facing this nation. In fact there was never a chance of No Deal.We will end up with a form of Chequers, but one even more pro-Brussels than the proposal which saw David Davis and BoJo storm out. Remainers are back in full Project Fear mode.European car firms are happily pouring billions into Britain — despite Brexit. Yet Greg Clark triggered last week’s chorus of fake alarm from Toyota, claiming its “just-in-time” supply chain would grind to a halt.This ignores the whole point of “just-in-time”. It is designed specically to cope with delivery glitches and operates worldwide in all circumstances under global trade rules.It was also Clark who handed Brussels its biggest anti-Brexit card by promising those shroud-waving car giants the UK would remain under EU rules. That led directly to Mrs May’s surrender over the Northern Ireland border, which has plagued negotiations ever since.It is a tragic fact — but no surprise — that we are now heading remorselessly for a deal on EU terms at our expense.EU leaders were never going to see us thrive outside. They insisted we will not be better off after Brexit.Anyone who hoped we might be set free to compete on equal terms should read ex-Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis’ story of his own country’s punishment beating.It was Varoufakis who compared Brexit with the Eagles’ hit: “It’s like Hotel Calornia — you can check out any time you like, but you can never leave.” And we can blame Phil Hammond for blocking the fire Brexits.But Ms Jourova, a Czech raised under Soviet rule, wants Corbyn-style “regulation” of the free Press.The apple never falls far from the tree.PS. I wonder how M Macron feels after Europe’s Ryder Cup triumph in Paris... without a single French golfer And SIX from the UK!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc press doesnt get tabloids right
story: Theories have ranged from Keeley Hawes’ acting to Richard Madden’s arse, without considering a more obvious possibility.Every other competing drama was either too dull , too grim , or just too rubbish.Which brings me to Press, a series I’d wanted to avoid on the obvious grounds there was never any possibility I was going to like a BBC drama about tabloids.But what the hell. It was a quiet week, so I watched the first four episodes and, to my surprise and delight, I hated Press even more than I expected.The set-up’s the deal-breaker, of course. We’ve got a right-wing red-top called The Post, that’s very obviously meant to be The Sun, and a left-wing broadsheet The Herald, which is equally obviously , house Bible of the BBC.The former is edited by soul-selling clone Duncan Allen, played by the brilliant Ben Chaplin, who does actually resemble a couple of ex-colleagues.By rights then, the female lead should be The Herald’s editor, Amina Chaudury, played by Priyanga Burford.But she can’t act, so the responsibility’s fallen to Charlotte Riley as northern, working-class brick of Deputy News Editor Holly Evans, who fits the social profile of your averagewoman about as comfortably as Roy Chubby Brown fits a mankini.Next weird thing you probably notice about Press is that nearly all the characters are giving speeches, rather than talking normally to each other.Especially the insufferable broadsheet hacks, who never stop reminding each other “we speak the truth to the powerful”, and that “people buy The Herald for the truth”.Why do people buy The Post Sun It’s never really occurred to writer Mike “Doctor Foster” Bartlett, who clearly didn’t read our newspaper before he sat down to type Press, at his desk on the summit of Mount Olympus, and has probably never met a tabloid reader either, without telling them: “Keep the change.”How can I be so sure Because it’s got almost every single professional and technical aspect wrong, from Duncan’s insistence he’s going to do a spread “On page five and six” , to the week one headline The Post produced about the gay, blackmailed footballer who committed suicide: “Parents never knew their son.”Which is the sort of meaningless, esoteric b******s that would get thrown back at a student newspaper sub.That’s another unconvincing thing about Press, incidentally. No one swears. And I wouldn’t mind so muchthere were some decent stories to see us through, but there aren’t.There’s a Katie Hopkins figure floating around, a few cut-and-pasted bits of very old tabloid legendand some deep state conspiracy cobblers, which the BBC’s probably got written into Raa Raa The Noisy Lion these days.Duncan also has the vague hots for Holly, until such time as Ed off the newsdesk tells him she likes having it off in a grey vest.That’s about your lot, though.As always happens when British TV tries to dramatise the Press, the writer’s left-of-centre political agenda and prejudices trump everything .This is why Americans do it so much better, andyou want to see how newspapers really operate you’ll get a much better idea from Billy Wilder’s  film The Front Page than you ever will from Press.I’ll say this for the BBC production team though, they might not have much of an ear for newspaper dialogue, but they’ve got a hell of an eye for interior design and have duplicated one item of our office kitchen crockery perfectly.Mugs.“I don’t bend in the middle any more, to be honest.”Then just slap him around a bit.Improvise, woman.FURTHER proof,it were needed, there’s not a single television format that can’t be improved by the presence of one or two of the Happy Mondays arrived on Friday.A special BBC Music Day edition of Bargain Hunt, featuring Bez and Rowetta versus Pulp’s Jarvis Cocker and Candida Doyle, which will go down in daytime TV folklore.Attempting to keep them in some sort of order, at the Kent showground’s antique fair, was BH regular Charlie Ross, who didn’t get very far with his preliminary question: “How did it all start with the Happy Mondays, Bez ”“You really don’t want to know.”So you really couldn’t blame him for looking a bit nervous when he sent the pair of them away with £ in used notes.Half an hour later, though, Bez and Rowetta were back, with three items, including a biscuit tin and a to-die-for rustic, bygone horse collar mirror that’s yours for just  quid.It made them a respectable £ profit at auction, as well, and flattened Pulp’s efforts in the process.At which point things got a bit dark.Charlie noted “an irregularity”, the Mondays were hauled back on set, like guilty schoolkids, and the host was forced to explain that the winsome and very obliging woman at the back of the auction hall, who kept bidding for his items was in fact: “Bez’s girlfriend.”Not angry, Bez, just disappointed.IF you’ve never seen the brilliant Simpsons episode where Homer gives Pinchy, his pet lobster, a really hot bath, Google it as soon as you can.Then immediately after, watch Channel ’s darkly funny latest episode of Celebrity Island With Bear Grylls, where a pig wandered into camp, on Sunday night.Even more obligingly it then started fattening itself up on the celebs’ leftovers and inviting the obvious by crapping its load everywhere.While some sensed dinner, Towie’s Pete Wicks had a better idea.He named the pig Colin, took it for a walk and then tethered it with a rope to some rocks.Whereupon Colin, with the sort of demonic squeals and grunts you last heard on Deliverance, promptly strangled himself to death.Presented with this tragedy, you or I or Martin Kemp from Spandau Ballet, might’ve drawn the obvious conclusion and, like Homer Simpson, tucked in Not this lot.Instead Colin was buried at sea, with full military honours, to avoid “hurting Pete’s feelings”, floating off into the sunset like a warning to humanity.This MorningSemra Haksever: “I call myself an eclectic witch, so I take dferent little bits of magic from all over the place.So it’s all b******sOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: budget must put money in pockets
story: For all the wise words in his conference speech — on the opportunities of new technology, the horric dangers of Corbyn’s socialism and the importance of job-creating businesses — he needs answers to more immediate questions.The signs are ominous. The Chancellor, while admitting “st Century capitalism must deliver” for ordinary people, apparently intends to take MORE of our money for the NHS in his upcoming Budget.Polls apparently show voters are OK with that. But wait till it comes out of wage packets. Skint workers won’t thank the Tories for bailing out the health ­service. They’ll desert them for grabbing yet more of their take-home pay.Mr Hammond’s speech wasn’t all bad. His case against socialism was well put. Likewise his view that no sane party should try to outbid Corbyn’s ruinous spending pledges. We welcome his proposed digital services tax on Google and Facebookit can be made to work. ut Tory fortunes hinge on Brexit — and pay rises easily outstripping inflation.The Budget MUST put more money in pockets . . . not remove it with a tax raid or a suicidal rise in fuel duty.THE EU’s cry-bullies are OUTRAGED that Jeremy Hunt compared their aggression to the old Soviet Union. Well, diddums.He noted, quite reasonably, that Brussels’ forcible attempts to lock Britain in and deter others from leaving was ­reminiscent of the Soviet empire’s treatment of its member states.It is a figure of speech. The Foreign Secretary’s not literally comparing Juncker to Stalin’s regime of mass murder. And the EU has no defence. Which is why its lackeys, such as curtain-haired clown Guy Verhofstadt, instead wilfully misinterpreted him for dramatic effect.One even whined it could “damage relations” with other member states. Are they for real  The French president brands Brexit campaigners “liars” — implying .million Brits are dupes. Donald Tusk humiliates our PM. But WE’RE in danger of souring relations.Give it a rest, EU fools.HOW appalling that the sisters of terror victim cop Keith Palmer have no Legal Aid to pursue the truth at his inquest.Michelle Palmer and Angela Clark want to hire an independent expert to assess whether a permanent armed presence at Parliament’s Carriage Gates entrance might have saved their brother.But the Legal Aid Agency hasn’t processed their application. Meanwhile the women claim the Met is actively hostile.Why are the Government and police making enemies of Keith’s family Justice Secretary David Gauke should grant them legal aid today.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: more young people are feeling lonely
story: The Eleanor Rigby of Beatles legend: “All the lonely people, where do they all come from ”An answer emerged this week — and they come from a surprising place.The loneliest people are healthy, thriving young adults, kicking off their career and probably renting a room in a city.According to new university research for the BBC, levels of loneliness are highest among  to -year-olds, with  per cent saying they often, or very often, feel it. In contrast, the over-s are positively chipper: Only  per cent of this group reported feelings of isolation.Now, I’m  and, depressingly, these statistics don’t surprise me.At first glance, it looks like young people have it easy when it comes to making friends.At  or thereabouts, more than  per cent of them will be packed off to university where they’ll move in with a group of like-minded people of the same age and be encouraged to drink and party like there’s no tomorrow.Which, when you’re only required to stumble out of bed for one pm lecture, there essentially isn’t.Rather than relying on friends of tenuous friends for dubious introductions, young people these days can simply download an app and get the details of thousands of eligible strangers delivered straight to their mobile phones.Add into the mix social media ­— which allows its users to connect with everyone they’ve ever met instantaneously at any given moment — and it’s hard to imagine how any young people could possibly be lonely, let alone  per cent.But there are two sides to every coin.University — though a godsend when it comes to meeting new people — can be a problem when it comes to staying in touch with them. Saddled with bottomless debt, young graduates simply don’t have the cash to socialise.When a round for six at a London pub will set you back  quid, is it any wonder that more and more young people are opting to stay at home Dating apps, too, come with their pitfalls. Yes, it’s nice to have a database of singletons in your pocket, but the ubiquity of Tinder and Bumble mean it’s now considered almost socially awkward to speak to someone you fancy in person.A friend of mine, who has absolutely no problem propositioning women on Tinder, hasn’t yet found the courage to ask for his next-door neighbour’s number, four months after she moved in.As for social media, young people like me are increasingly discovering that “staying connected” is a mixed blessing at best. With no excuse to lose touch, my generation holds on to friends we’ve outgrown, leaving us with no time to make new ones. It may sound callous, but there’s an art to shedding friends, and thanks to our social media addiction, we seem to have lost it.What’s more, earnest  to -year-olds seem to be taking to heart the faddish health advice that adults have been merrily ignoring for years, making it even harder for them to socialise because they fear alcohol, and even food.At the end of a recent party I got chatting to a fun young woman, so I suggested some pub grub at a boozer to round off the evening. How wrong I was.She explained in detail she was vegan and on a gluten-free diet , so the pub menu would not cater for her needs.I decided not to pursue it.So I say it’s time snowflake millennials took a bit of responsibility for their own feelings of isolation.Last month commentators wagged their fingers at the big tech companies after a survey by charity YoungMinds revealed a greater number of young people view social media as having a negative impact on the way they feel about themselves than those who report a positive impact.But it was never suggested depressed young people should simply put away their phones and do something .Mollycoddled millennials believe having a thriving social circle is a human right, rather than an ongoing project.Instead of popping to the pub for a pick-me-up with whoever happens to be around, a lonely young person will all too often turn to the internet for a spot of indulgent self-reflection, or to the gym for Insta-friendly self-improvement.As a result, pubs are closing at a rate of  a day, and sites such as Tumblr are overflowing with posters instructing users to “forget the haters” and “shine like the star that you are”.Of course, social media is made to be addictive. But surely putting down a phone can’t be an insurmountable challenge for an educated generation of young people  Dwelling on yourself is the surest route to a lonely lestyle, so instead of posting doleful, introspective memes on social media or clinging to tired old friendships, lonely young people should find the guts to get outside and look outwards.Making and keeping real friends takes work, and it’s time young people started putting the hours in.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tropical storm leslie hurricane heading uk
story: With wind speeds of mph and even stronger gusts, the storm is now looking much more severe than previously predicted.Extremely powerful hurricane-force winds are already extending  miles from the centre of the vast storm, with slightly weaker tropical-storm-force winds covering a whopping  mile area.Storm Leslie is in the middle of the Atlantic right now.It is forecast to head north towards the US over the next couple of days - before changing direction and barrelling off towards Europe on Sunday.Previous reports of the strengthening storm said that Britain could expect fierce gales and torrential rain as the storm moved eastwards towards Europe, although its exact path was yet to be confirmed.Now weathermen have confirmed that the storm is heading our way, with charts showing the storms path curving menacingly up towards Britain.A Met Office Spokesman told The Sun Online: “Quite often by the time anything comes anywhere near the UK, all we’re left with is a bit of energy in the system rather than anything that vaguely resembles a hurricane.“But at the moment it’s far too early to say exactly where it will track and what stage it will be at as it crosses the Atlantic.“As it starts moving in our direction, we’ll get a better idea of how near to us what’s left will come, whether there’s anything that will affect our weather at all.“And it’s not likely to come in our direction till next week, probably mid-to late I would think, but it’s still a fairly fluid situation at the moment.Brian Gaze, director and forecaster for the Weather Outlook, told The Sun Online: Its too early to be certain about the impact of Storm Leslie on the UKs weather, but at the moment it looks like tracking to our northwest.That means a northwest to southeast split in the weather would be likely.In the north west of the UK there is the potential for it to turn very wet and windy.Areas farther south and east could remain dry, and possibly become very warm for the time of the year as tropical air embedded in the system crosses the UK.Some computer models show temperatures pushing up towards the mid Cs in the south east.However, it is too early to discount the chance of the wet and windy weather extending farther southeastwards.The enormous hurricane winds will blow over a huge  mile area, with less intense winds reaching as far as  milesEffects wont be felt in the UK until next week after Leslie has moved up towards the America.The National Hurricane Center in Miami has warned that large swells and rip tides could be le-threatening as the brutal storm closes in on the southeastern coast of the United States along with Bermuda and the Bahamas in the next few days.Before Leslies effects are felt in the UK, the south east is in for another warm spell today and for the next few days.The Met Office said: Given a good spell of sunshine we could see a C or C in London today, and tomorrow it will be similar.We could be looking at a C or C even on Thursday and Friday.The south east will also see the highest temperatures over the weekend.A weather front from northern Scotland will head down across the country on Thursday bringing some potentially heavy rain but winds will be mostly slow moving.Another front from the northwest will then descend to the southeast on Friday which could mean stronger downpours in northern England and Wales, as well as southern Scotland.The weekend is generally going to be cloudier and cooler, with rains following the weather fronts.It should dry up in the south east of England on Sunday but it will be a cold and bright day.

title: idiots attempt to dive into a swimming pool from a roof ends in a spectacular faceplant
story: Footage of the unidentied man leaves viewers wincing as he misses the water by inches, and his body slams the ground.It is not as yet known where or when the stomach-churning footage – shared on social media – was filmed, or what injuries he suffered.The video shows a half-naked man standing on the roof of a changing room, after climbing up a ladder.Pals appear unfazed as he lines himself up for the jump with one even talking casually on his mobile phone.But as the man walks down towards the gutter, with his head tipping forward, he raises his arms and plunges too soon.Arms flailing in the air, the wannabe er smashes through the guttering and lands on all fours while his head bounces on the hard concrete surrounding the swimming pool.The footage blurs as those watching and filming his painful stunt yell out and rush to help the man, who appears to be knocked out as a result.The six-second video has been widely shared on social media in recent days.

title: theresa may dances onto stage for tory party conference speech
story: The PM poked fun at her Maybot image as she got her groove on to Abbas Dancing Queen before appealing to the party to get behind her.And in a blast at Boris Johnson, Mrs May warned that anyone obsessed with getting the perfect Brexit risk leaving us tied to the EU forever.She also took a pop at the top Brexiteer over his f**k business jibe - vowing to back business instead.In the hour-long address, the PM:She admitted that the public needed to see that their hard work has paid off after struggling with cuts to public services in a bid to balance the countrys books.But in a blow to MPs who want to see her gone, Mrs May insisted she has a plan for the next year and beyond.The address received a massive standing ovation from activists, as husband Philip walked on stage and kissed her while ELOs Mr Blue Sky played over the PR.In her speech in Birmingham, the PM gave a spirited defence of her Chequers plan which has ided MPs and activists.She said: “We will not betray the result of the referendum, and we will never break up our country.“I have treated the EU with nothing but respect. The UK expects the same.”The PM added that her plan would respect the referendum while minimising the economic dangers.She said: “It delivers on the referendum. It keeps fair with the British people. It is in the national interest.”Hitting out at hard Brexiteers such as Boris Johnson, the PM added: Those of us who do respect the result, whichever side of the question we stood on two years ago, need to come together now.If we dont -we all go off in dferent directions in pursuit of our own visions of the perfect Brexit - we risk ending up with no Brexit at all.In a second dig at Boris - who has overshadowed the conference by making his own alternative leadership pitch - Mrs May said Tories shouldnt be saying f**k business as he did earlier this year.She said: To all business - large and small - you may have heard that there is a four-letter word to describe what we Conservatives want to do to you.It has a single syllable. It is of Anglo Saxon derivation. It ends in the letter K. Back business!Mrs May vowed to bring an end to austerity after a decade-long financial squeeze, telling hard-pressed voters: “The end is in sight.”Praising the fall in the deficit, she added: “This is a historic achievement - but getting to this turning point wasn’t easy.“Public sector workers had their wages frozen, local services had to do more with less, and families felt the squeeze.“Fixing our finance was necessary - there must be noto the uncontrolled borrowing the past, no undoing all of the progress of the last eight years, no taking Britain back to square one.“But the British people need to know that the end is in sight. And our message to them must be this - we get it.”The PM revealed the Government will turn on the spending taps again next year once theyve finished the job of cutting a Brexit deal with Brussels.And she delivered a love letter to Britain, listing the countrys achievements and adding: Dont let anyone tell you we dont have what it takes.Mrs May also launched a blistering attack on Jeremy Corbyn - warning that Tories have a “duty” to keep him out of power.The PM said the Labour boss was making Jewish Brits feel unsafe in their own country and claimed the party has lost its moral backbone.Mrs May said: “The Jeremy Corbyn party rejects the common values that once bridged our political ide.”She added: What has befallen Labour is a national tragedy.She went on: What has it come to when Jewish families today seriously discuss where they should goJeremy Corbyn becomes Prime Minister That is what Jeremy Corbyn has done to the Labour party. It is our duty, in this Conservative party, to make sure he can never do it to our country.THERESA May tried to overcome last years disastrous conference speech by making a string of jokes about it.After she came on shimmying to Abbas Dancing Queen - mocking her cringey dance moves form a recent trip to Africa, she joked that some could even have been inspired to become professional dancers after seeing her moves. months ago Mrs May was forced to stop several times during her crunch speech while she tried to clear her throat.But she laughed it off today, telling the audience: Youll have to excuse meI cough during this speech.The PM has been suffering with a snfle for the last few days, sparking fears of another spluttering disaster.And she quipped on the backdrop which came down last year as she was talking, saying: Ive been up all night super-gluing the backdrop.Mrs May also made a stinging joke about her ex-Cabinet colleague Boris Johnson, who gave a barn-storming speech to activists yesterday.A few months ago he caused uproar by reportedly uttering the words f**k business.But lashing back, Mrs May said today: And to all business - large and small - you may have heard that there is a four-letter word to describe what we Conservatives want to do to you.It has a single syllable. It is of Anglo Saxon derivation. It ends in the letter K. Back business.After talking about her Housing Secretary James Brokenshire’s treatment and recovery from cancer, the PM revealed her own goddaughter died from the disease last year.She said: “Cancer can strike any of us at any time.“A few years ago my goddaughter was diagnosed with cancer.“She underwent treatment and it seemed to be working, then the cancer came back.“Last summer she sent me a text to tell me she was hoping to see another Christmas. But she didn’t make it.”Senior Tories hailed the PM’s speech - comparing it favourably to last year’s total meltdown.Jeremy Hunt said: “Congratulations Theresa May for a remarkable speech delivered with humour and passion.“Firmness of purpose, clarity and conviction - EU friends do not underestimate!”And Downing Street chief of staff Gavin Barwell quipped on Twitter: “Waited  months for that #outthepark”.But Labour dismissed her speech as empty rhetoric - shadow minister Andrew Gwynne said: Try telling local government across England there’s an end to austerity... deep cuts to our public services are continuing and they have Theresa May’s fingerprints all over them!And Lib Dem boss Vince Cable joked: “As somebody who takes dancing seriously, I was delighted to see Theresa May show that she is developing her new hobby. But she was dancing on the head of a pin, confronted by an audience full of people plotting to oust her.The PM said during her conference speech: “Something’s changed for the worse. Rigorous debate between political opponents is becoming more like a confrontation between enemies.“People who put themselves forward are becoming targets, their families as well.“We all saw the sickening pictures of a far-left extremist shouting abuse at Jacob Rees-Mogg’s children.“And it’s not only Conservatives who are facing abuse the first black woman ever to be elected to the House of Commons receives more racist and misogynist messages today than when she first stood over  years ago.“You don’t have to agree with a word Diane Abbott says to believe passionately in her right to say it free from threats and abuse.”Ms Abbott, the Shadow Home Secretary, welcomed her nice words but lashed out at the Tories for deliberately targeting her with their adverts during last years election.She tweeted: Some nice words from Tory leaders like Theresa May and Sajid Javid. Makes you wonder who was responsible for the Tory party’s relentless personal attacks in the general election campaign .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the worlds weirdest records revealed as ketchup drinkers and scooter riding dogs honoured
story: Theres also the most toilet seats broken by the head in a minute, the longest time spent kissing a car and the farthest eyeball protrusion.Brits apparently can’t get enough of the Guinness Book of World Records, with a fth apparently willing to risk injury just to get into it.A study of , UK adults revealed half had owned a copy at some point, a quarter dreamed of featuring in it and five per cent have tried to do just that.The same proportion were so desperate to appear in the book they had actually lied about being in it.Given the range of records on offer, there may yet be hope for many.One man was the first to surf a wave while on fire, another qualied for having the largest collection of rubber ducks.A whole heap of people snuck in as the largest gathering of people dressed as Mahatma Gandhi.Then there were records for most apples held in the mouth and cut in half by chainsaw, and the heaviest weight pulled by pierced ears.Lottoland commissioned the research after securing their own title for largest online gambling pay-out.This was achieved after a -year old cleaner from Berlin won a Eurojackpot.As well as commissioning the research into just how much Brits loved the records book, Lottoland will also be running a record EuroMillionaire jackpot in its honour.The grand prize will equal £m on its October  draw.Lottoland CEO Nigel Birrell said: “If you win either jackpot you would break the Guinness World Record we have just set for the largest online gambling payout.”Other achievements recorded include a woman with the longest legs, and a teen taekwondo champion who broke  cement blocks with his head.Recently a BMW also claimed the record of the longest journey made by an electric vehicle - covering , miles.

title: theresa may push lock brexit deal
story: The PM will start phoning leaders across Europe’s capitals this morning in a bid to close gaping gaps.Now that the high risk moment of the Tories’ annual conference in Birmingham is over, senior government figures say she is freer to make more potentially controversial compromises.Despite Mrs May’s demand for Brussels to end the new impasse after the Salzburg summit disaster, The Sun can also reveal that secret talks have already reopened.The PM’s chief negotiator Olly Robbins has been in Brussels this week to try to hammer out a backstop plan to ensure no Irish border.One Cabinet minister involved in the process told The Sun: “We need some very fancy footwork to get the Withdrawal Agreement wrapped up by the October council.“But deadlines always concentrate minds.The PM will be hitting the phone hard and we think it’s just about doable.”The EU announced last night that its  leaders will meet to discuss Brexit over dinner on October , the night before the next summit starts.But Britain has been told that the pieces for a orce deal must be in place by the start of that week for national capitals to then consider them.The UK’s new proposal involves “spreading the pain” over where Ireland’s future customs and regulatory borders lie three ways, between the EU, the UK and Ireland.The EU’s plan for a border down the Irish Sea has been firmly rejected by Mrs May.And her bid to collect the EU’s tarfs and keep Britain within a close customs arrangement has been ruled out by Brussels, along with any infrastructure on the Irish border.No wants to agree the full orce deal at the summit on October -, but hold back from writing it into legal text.A further intensive four week negotiation will then take place before another Brexit summit in November to agree the future framework for a UK-EU trade deal, before both are then signed at the same time.Of all the  EU leaders, French president Emmanuel is still seen as the hardest and most important nut to crack, as German boss Angela Merkel is still too distracted by her unstable coalition government in Berlin.Irish PM Leo Varadkar will touch down in Brussels today for talks with chief negotiator Michel Barnier and EU Council president Donald Tusk.EU diplomats are also increasingly hopeful of achieving a major breakthrough on the thorny border issue within two weeks.One EU diplomat told The Sun: Perhaps its one of the elements where we can move.Im more optimistic than I have been for months that a deal is possible. But they cautioned against overinflated expectations, adding: Dont be too hopeful of having white smoke.October is important but its about trying to get some feel good back into the talks and seeing whether there is indeed land in sight.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab is then expected to go to the Belgian capital next week.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: conservative party brexit unity rod liddle opinion
story: I don’t think Theresa May is going to be on Strictly any time soon. Whoever convinced her it would be dead cool to walk on stage at the party conference and jig about to an Abba song needs a bit of invasive brain surgery, right now.It was like a remake of Re-Animator, or Night Of The Living Dead.There’s no point in Theresa trying to tell us she’s the le and soul of the party and actually a bloody good laugh.We know she isn’t. She’s about as charismatic as an underdone crumpet on a wet Sunday. But she doesn’t need to be Ginger Rogers. She’s the Prime Minister.And you have to give her credit for doggedly sticking to that role. EvenI’m not convinced she’s been doing it terribly well.But on Brexit — God, how mind-numbingly boring the whole thing is — she has a good point.I’m not a fan of her Chequers deal for us to leave the European Union. I think we’re giving too much away. I’d rather have a no-deal exit.But time is pressing. And I’m aware that while we Leavers won the referendum, the margin was comparatively small. So we ought to be gracious and accept a little bit of a compromise. Try to strike a respectable deal with those gangsters from insignicant countries.And a little further down the line, tweak the arrangements a little to suit us better. In the meantime, just strike the deal.And that means getting behind May and presenting a united front to Europe. Most of the Conservative MPs understand that, even the arch-Brexiteers like the excellent Michael Gove.But Bfo the Blundering Bear does not. I’m talking about Boris Johnson. Now he IS fun and good company. But he’s about as likely to become Prime Minister as I am to cop off with Emily Ratajkowski after a few pints and a quick meal at the Chicken Cottage.He has very little support among his political colleagues. He has a lot more among Conservative activists. But very little among voters north of Watford.And yet Bfo was at it again this week. Taking the p**s out of the Prime Minister. And making a rousing speech to his hardcore supporters. Demanding we tell the EU to stuff it.Well, there was a time when we should have told the EU to stuff it — two years ago when we first started negotiations.That time has passed. A lack of confidence from the Government and a ided party let us down.Now is the time to show a bit of unity and wring a deal out of the deathly bureaucrats. Maybe not the Chequers deal — May didn’t mention the word at all during her speech — but a version of it.Otherwise we’ll have a General Election on our hands. One the Tories will lose. And you’ll wake up to find John McDonnell is in charge of your finances and Diane Abbott is Home Secretary.Come on — surely that should concentrate the mind a little Hero of the week is Jane Lunnon, head of a girls’ school in South London.She has stuck the boot into “image-obsessed” reality TV – especially that coven of gurning and pouting imbeciles in Love Island, such as Megan Barton Hanson.Such programmes are “incredibly damaging” to young people, she reckons, calling them “trivial nonsense”.I think Jane is right. And the same goes for all those hyped-up talent shows where people with no talent – just a lust for fame – get judged on their appalling performances by people with no talent.Kids need to know the dference between fame for fame’s sake – and real achievement.Its horrible that Corine Remande has lost the sight in one eye after she was hit by a golf ball during the Ryder Cup.The poor woman was standing among spectators when Brooks Koepka’s tee shot hit her in the face.She’s now threatening legal action against the organisers. She says they didn’t give spectators enough protection.This is ludicrous. What were they supposed to do And what will happen is that in future crowds will be kept even further back from the action. Just because of one horrible accident.Wait until the same thing happens in cricket...The uni magazine said: “It was argued that the loud noise of traditional clapping and whooping pose an issue to students with anxiety or sensory issues. BSL clapping – or, jazz hands – would be a more inclusive form of expression.”With anxiety or sensory issues  What is wrong with these people They are “triggered” by almost everything. Especially by people who have views which dfer from their own.That REALLY triggers them. They shouldn’t be at university. They should be safe at home with mummy and daddy.That old windbag Mahathir Mohamad has been visiting the UK.Lovely to have him, of course. He’s the boss of Muslim-dominated Malaysia and he hates Jews.He was at it again over here. Said they all had “hook noses”.And that they were the cause of all the trouble in the Middle East.He’s allowed his view, of course, evenit is one based on hatred and the ideology of his own interpretation of his religion.But how would it beI said Muslims are the cause of most of the trouble in the world I’d be up before the Old Bill for a hate crime before you could say Islamic State.This is because Asian countries are getting more and more wealthy.I suppose this is a good thing. Problem is, I can’t stand them, the middle class.And the thought of nearly four billion people eating avocado on toast while doing Pilates then listening to Coldplay in their Volvo XCs makes me feel terribly queasy.The human race is being taken over by the legions of the smug. Get me outta here.Visitors to the Telford Exotic Zoo were disappointed by the penguins. They just stood, stock still.This is because they are plastic model penguins. The zoo had been unable to get the real thing.And here’s a tip for the zoo owners. Don’t buy any real penguins, stick to the models.I think plastic penguins would be far better suited to an enclosure of a dozen square yards of shingle with a tiny drainage ditch to bathe in.Why are we allowing zoos like this to open  If I were a real penguin in Telford Exotic Zoo I’d sue them. Or beat them about the head with a flipper.Have you seen Vladimir Putin’s new calendar There he is, standing naked in water, muscles rippling, looking stern.Another one has him cuddling a baby leopard.I hate to say this but isn’t it all a bit... um... camp And now for saying this I’ll probably end up resembling one of the glow sticks the kids buy at funfairs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm austerity over build houses
story: The PM used her annual conference speech as a giant job interview for her to remain as the nation’s leader after Brexit.With plots to oust her after March  mounting following a major revolt over her soft Brexit plan, Mrs May charmed the hall with a flurry of gags — and even danced her way on stage to her favourite Abba song, Dancing Queen.Her speech was seen as a clear plea for more time as she told the audience: “Our future is in our hands.“We stand at a pivotal moment in our history. It falls to our party to lead our country through it.”Top of Mrs May’s list of fresh ­policy offers was a major move to get thousands more frustrated families on the housing ladder.She announced the Government is to scrap a long-standing cap on how much councils can borrow against their current housing stock to build more homes.There are .million households on the waiting list, but only , homes were made available in .Explaining the change in thinking, Mrs May said: “We cannot make the case for capitalismordinary working people have no chance of owning capital.Solving the housing crisis is the biggest domestic policy challenge of our generation.“It doesn’t make sense to stop councils from playing their part in solving it.”The state will also spend more from next year while still keeping the nation’s finances under control, the PM pledged.In answer to pleas for more cash to ease the pressure on Britain’s crowded schools, stretched hospitals and creaking defences, she promised that “support for public services will go up”.Mrs May added: “Because you made sacrices, there are better days ahead.“A decade after the financial crash, people need to know that the austerity it led to is over and that their hard work has paid off.”Issuing her final plea for unity, the PM ended her address with the declaration: “When we come together, there is no limit to what we can achieve.”Her speech brought a long standing ovation from the audience in Birmingham — appearing to have won over sceptical Tory activists for now.Only minutes before Mrs May began her address yesterday lunchtime, one angry Brexiteer MP issued a withering demand that she resign.Ex-minister James Duddridge wrote to the backbench Tory  Committee to call for a no confidence vote in the PM.Branding her incapable of leadership, he said: “Blind loyalty is not the right way forward.”And hours later, Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom refused to back Mrs May to lead the Tories into the next general election.She told ITV’s Peston show: “I just think politics is a short-term game. A week changes a lot.”But loyalist Cabinet ministers were delighted with her performance.Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab hailed it a “speech laden with leadership”.Torbjörn Sohlström — ambassador for Abba’s homeland of Sweden — was among those to see Mrs May’s attention-grabbing entry to the hall. He tweeted: “I can only say ‘bravo’.”The PM’s robotic dancing became a worldwide phenomenon in August when TV images of her trying to join in with children in Africa went viral.However, councils and campaigners were more impressed with the scrapping of the borrowing cap and the fresh trust ministers were placing on local authorities.Homeless charity Shelter’s boss Polly Neate called it “a major reform that shows real intent to back social house-building”.. Theresa May has a good sense of humour. She stunned Tories by entering the stage dancing to Abba’s Dancing Queen and making gags at her own expense, including a risque nod to steamy BBC drama Bodyguard.. She really cant stand Boris. The PM couldn’t even bring herself to use his name when she swiped out at him over reports he said “f*** business” in response to their Brexit concerns.. Her Chequers Brexit proposal is so toxic she couldnt say the word once in her -minute speech. She also name-checked the NHS more than Brexit -  times to .. She made it clear who wears trousers between her and Downing Street neighbour Philip Hammond, pinching his two big Budget announcements on fuel duty and a house building splurge, plus beating the Chancellor to it to declare an end to austerity.. Mrs May has no intention of standing down soon despite the Cabinet jockeying for her job by trying to renew her domestic vision so it lasts long after Brexit. But Lib Dem Sir Vince Cable, who appeared on a Strictly special in , said: “As somebody who takes dancing seriously, I was delighted to see Theresa May show that she is developing her new hobby.“But she was dancing on the head of a pin, confronted by an audience full of people plotting to oust her.”Labour’s Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell dubbed her claim that austerity is over as “a con”.ligtGOT a story  Ring The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or email exclusive@the-sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rooting against cashless britain
story: But in just ten years’ time, kids will find the idea of a porcelain container for metal coins ridiculous — and will be doing their saving on a phone app with cute graphics.Face it, cash is dying out. It is dirty and unhygienic — a report out this week said it is a breeding ground for bugs.There is even a version of Monopoly with debit cards instead of notes. And last month we told you of the  century The Boot pub in Freston, Suffolk, the first boozer in the country to go cashless.This looming death has been around for a while. In August, the Bank of England said it was considering phasing out p and p coins. And ATMs are closing at a rate of  a month.Just  per cent of payments are cash, down from  per cent in . And those payments only account for three per cent in terms of the value of how much is spent.Paying on card has been on the rise ever since Barclaycard launched in , but cards too face being eclipsed by payments on mobile phones. Either way, both mean we need cash less. And that is not a bad thing, right Getting rid of cash would hit criminals and tax evaders hard as they do business in cash to make it harder for authorities to track the movement of money.Businesses would rejoice because they would not have to pay security guards to transport money and would not have to spend ages counting and bagging it.Some also reckon it is easier to keep a tab on finances when spending on cards or apps. You might forget buying that extra round at closing time in the pub, but your phone will always remember. And of course, you get consumer protection when using a credit card, along with reward points or cashback offers.Credit card firms make their money not just from interest payments but from taking a small fee for each transaction — so they offer us incentives to choose their cards. Use an Air Miles card and before long you could have a free flight to Paris or New York.More than a quarter of clothes in the UK are bought online — and you can’t use cash over the internet. As we move even more to buying online and via smartphone apps, cash will be needed less and less. Whether cash dies out in five years or  or  just depends on technology.But many are in no rush to see the back of it — and not just because of nostalgia for their old piggy banks. One consideration is: Can we entirely trust the banks to look after our money  Fraud is soaring as criminals take advantage of security issues around online banking. Banks blame customers but critics say banks need to take responsibility.We have featured victim after victim on The Sun Money columns, and they all say bank staff have turned their backs on them. There are millions of others who need cash simply because they rely on it to pay for things day to day. And it is the less well off or elderly who rely on it the most.Consumer magazine Which  — which has been campaigning against the loss of banks and ATMs — has produced research showing poorer families and older folk are hardest hit.Gareth Shaw of Which  said: “ATM and branch closures are threatening to leave behind the millions who still rely on cash. Our research highlights lower-income families and older generations will be among the worst hit.”In June, services from Visa, one of the three main card providers along with Mastercard and American Express, went down with technical issues — highlighting the risk of being solely reliable on cards and phones. “When the trolley came around on the train and the card payment wasn’t working, the only people who could eat were those with cash,” one banker explained.And what about hospitality workers  The Government has said all tips, evenon cards, must go to staff — but we all know some unscrupulous bosses will not do that. Like many, I prefer to give my tips in cash so I know the waiter or waitress gets it all.Charity collectors often have card machines now but collections for most churches, schools and small local good causes still rely on tins and the rattle of coins.Cash may well be dying out, but I still make sure I always keep some coins in my pocket just in case. And I have older relatives who still feel most comfortable with coins and notes.So until we have a population where everyone feels happy when using a card or phone, I will be rooting against a completely cashless Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The PM yesterday confirmed she was freezing duty for the ninth year in a row – to “put more money in the pockets of hard-working people”.Campaigners reacted with delight – and called for the PM to do even more for ‘strivers’ battling a ever higher cost of living.Tory ex-Minister Rob Halfon said: “Thanks to the Sun motorists are not going to be taken for a ride with extra taxes. story: But when the audacious scam emerged, the story shocked America and led to questions over how schools across the country had allowed this to happen.Con artist Johnson was expected to graduate from Lanier High School in Austin, Texas, in , but appeared to fall out of the school system.But at the age of , she finally graduated from nearby Garza Independent High School, a special school for students unsuitable for mainstream classrooms, in .However, devious Johnson was still more than a decade from finishing her school career as she conned teachers and dodged her way through the school system until the age of .The con artist even wore Hello Kitty and Minnie Mouse accessories at New Le Christian School in Longview, Texas, and continued the brazen charade on social media for seven months in .But Johnson was arrested on suspicion of failure to ID herself and giving  and fictitious information.However, police and school officials still, four years on, cannot identy why the suspect spent the best part of a school year pretending to be a pupil.Johnson called Osarieme Obaseki, who runs What About Us, a non-profit group for women and girls in need, posed as a -year-old girl and called Ms Obaseki mom.But she became suspicious and told the authorities in June , Buzzfeed says.Johnsons boyfriend, -year-old Rickie Williams, was stunned to learn of her arrest. He told KLTV: “My best friend showed me and I was shocked.He claims Johnson told him she was .Johnson, who even had a part-time job at McDonalds during the months she lied to attend school, has claimed she was abandoned by her drug-addict mother and jailed father when she was growing up.The con artist pleaded guilty to her charges in June .

title: presidential alert thousands americans mock twitter emergency text alerts
story: Phones across the the United States today received the first-ever mock national wireless emergency alert.The subject of the alert read: Presidential Alert. This is a test of the National Wireless Emergency Alert System. No action is needed.Officials estimated that about  million devices would receive the alert at about the same time, but the message was broadcast by mobile towers for  minutes so some people got it later than others.Some got as many as four alerts on their phones, others did not get any.And some took it as an opportunity to poke fun at the president.Ricky Gervais wrote: Cant wait for the first ever presidential alert saying that SNL sucks.Actor and activist George Takei tweeted: Oh my. A Presidential Alert emergency. I thought that was the entire Trump presidency.Model Chrissy Teigen added: NOOOOOOO THE ALERT. IT HAPPENED.@jlazebnik joked: Congrats to tfany trump, who just received her first ever text from her dad!@GoDiegitoGo said: Trump has been the only person to text me all week.In a real emergency, devices would get the alert at the same time or as close to the same time as possible.The system test is for a high-level presidential alert that would be used only in a nationwide emergency.Users cant opt out of the presidential alerts, which are issued at the direction of the White House but cannot be used for any sort of personal message from a president, according to officials.

title: ap photographer max nash conflicts royal family 40 years
story: Nash, who covered conflicts in Southeast Asia and the Middle East, was found dead after collapsing at home.The famed photographer shot everything from war zones, celebrity events and politics before retiring from The Associated Press in .He didnt want to hang up his cameras, though, and continued working as a freelancer for more than a decade.On his LinkedIn Page Nash wrote: Because I never found the job boring and still dont, I continue at .His iconic pictures captured Royal weddings, famous faces and war zones.Nash took images of Britains new Prime Minister Tony Blair entering Downing Street,  Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis in Israel and Prince William and Kate shortly after their wedding.Even sport got the Nash treatment with Manchester Uniteds Denis Irwin pictured being tackled by Chas Eddie Newton during the FA Cup final in .London born Nash first studied photography under his father, former Paris AP photo editor Michael OReilly Nash.He worked first for The New York Times before joining the AP bureau in Brussels in .That posting gave him his first experience in a war zone as conflict gripped Belgiums former colony in the Republic of Congo.Nash arrived at Saigons AP Bureau in late , joining Horst Faas and Carl Robinson as the bureaus photo editors.Nash told colleagues he often wore a helmet in Saigon not out of fear of bombardment, but because Faas would hit him over the head for mistyped captions.He also worked in Cambodia in the uncertain days after U.S.-backed Gen. Lon Nol overthrew Prince Norodom Sihanouk in .Some  foreign journalists were captured and killed by Khmer Rouge guerrillas after the coup, and former AP correspondent Jeff Williams recalled an incident in which he is certain that Nash saved his le due to his fluency in French.The photographer then covered the Israeli occupation of Lebanon, the Palestinian uprising and riots in the West Bank and Gaza in the late s.Those heavy combat assignments were followed by the First Gulf War and a rash of bombings in Israel in the mid-s.He later transferred to London, covering the British royals, the violence in Northern Ireland, Red Carpet events and car racing.Former bureau chief Myron Belkind: He never slowed down.Even when he finished an assignment, he wouldto the bureau and stay late to see what he could do to help his colleagues.Nash is survived by his children, Eleanor and Michael his brother, Tim and his grandchildren, Benjamin, Livi and Shelley.

title: theresa may chucks chequers sort of in conference speech
story: But once the self-deprecating opening was out of the way the prime minister moved on to addressing the major challenges she faces.The messages about ending austerity, tackling the pressures of the rising cost of living and fixing broken markets were ato the "burning injustices" theme she identied as her priorities when she first became leader.Her attacks on Labour, and Jeremy Corbyn in particular, reflected increasing concern that what she described as the oppositions "bogus solutions" are being taken more and more seriously by voters.And yet it was always going to be her comments on Brexit, the internal party isions and torrid negotiating process that would be listened to most keenly by those in the hall.
