title: 5 tory conference speech announcements
story: News announcements in Theresa Mays conference speech that will directly affect YOUR leCancer screening, petrol bills and affordable homes - here are the actual concrete policies revealed at the Conservative Party Conference ShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video pivotal-moments-theresa-mays-speech-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May today launched a last-ditch bid to keep her premiership alive with poundbillion in spending with an all-singing, all-dancing Tory conference speech - literally. The desperate PM jigged on stage to Abbas Dancing Queen as she admitted for the first time that the Tory civil war over Brexit is harming her ability to get a good deal. Introduced by booming-voiced Tory Geoffrey Cox, she poked fun at Brexiteer Boris Johnson, heaped praise on business and free markets and fearfully attacked Jeremy Corbyn as he inches microscopically closer to power. But with all the over-the-top theatrics in Birmingham, you may have missed some big new policies - that will directly affect your le.  Promising to finally bring an end to eight years of savage Tory cuts, the Prime Minister pledged a poundbillion housing boost and a poundmillion fuel duty freeze. There was also a poignant tale of her goddaughter behind introducing a new cancer screening regime. Here are the things you actually NEED to know from todays big event.  Theresa May announced the first details of a new cancer strategy after poignantly revealing her goddaughter died of the disease. She pledged that by , , more people will be alive five years after diagnosis than today. The age for full bowel cancer screening will drop from  to  in a bid to raise the early detection rate, currently around %, to around % by . Currently a one-off screening is available from age  but screening every two years is only available from age . The NHS will invest in new scanners and build more Rapid Diagnostic Centres – one stop-shops that help people get treatment quicker.  Theresa May’s spokesman said more details of her cancer strategy - including how much it will cost - will only be revealed by the end of the year, when the NHS’s future plan is published. My goddaughter was diagnosed with cancer, she revealed. It came back and last summer sent me a text saying she was hoping to see another Christmas. “But she didn’t make it.” No further details of Mrs Mays goddaughter, including her age or name, have been released, on request of her family. . Fuel duty is frozen for the th time - while other groups suffer  The Tory government will freeze fuel duty for the ninth year in a row, in a move that will cost taxpayerspoundmillion. Scrapping the planned p-a-litre rise will be in the Budget in four weeks time. This is the very first policy from that Budget that weve had confirmed. It will benefit hard-pressed motorists. But it comes as other groups continue to struggle - with working-age benefits still frozen for four years to . Tory officials suggest the average motorist has gained about pound, in total from all the freezes since . Now compare that to the utterly astronomical cost.  The Institute for Fiscal Studies estimates the cumulative effect of all those freezes is now costing the Treasury poundbillion a year. Thats more than the affordable housing budget and more than DOUBLE the amount gained by the government by freezing millions of peoples benefits. Greenpeace campaigner Morten Thaysen said: Instead of subsidising diesel and petrol May should be incentivising the take up of cleaner electric vehicles, and ensuring cheap and reliable public transport for all.  The borrowing cap imposed on local councils will be scrapped completely in a move that is expected to raise an extra poundbillion a year for housebuilding. It is a victory for councils after they spent years calling for the move, only to be rebuffed by the Tory government. But it wasnt immediately clear today whether the changes will have to be approved in Parliament.  Housing groups gave a cautious welcome. Chartered Institute of Housing director Gavin Smart said: “This is excellent news and we look forward to seeing the detail. The Federation of Master Builders branded the decision a victory for common sense. Ruth Davison of the National Housing Federation said: For years, everyone who builds affordable homes – both councils and housing associations – have argued this cap on council borrowing puts the brakes on building more homes. . Foreign home buyers will face a new tax  Mrs May revealed plans to slap an extra tax on foreign buyers of UK homes - and pour the proceeds into the governments rough sleeping strategy. A consultation will be launched on putting an extra rate of stamp duty on those who buy a home in the UK, but do not pay tax here. Tory chiefs said a higher % charge was already added to second and buy-to-let homes worth between pound, and pound.million. The new rate has not yet been set. But it would supposedly help youyoure trying to buy a home by wiping out unfair, foreign competition. . Austerity is over - but with a huge catch  The Prime Minister declared austerity is over after eight gruelling years. This isnt a concrete policy but,she keeps her word, itd have a huge impact on your family. The Prime Minister vowed to invest in public services and renew the NHS in her address to the faithful in Birmingham - despite benefits remaining frozen and cuts hitting Universal Credit. But there was a catch. She phrased her speech to say austerity will end AFTER she gets a good Brexit deal. That leaves open the suggestion thatshe DOESNT get a Brexit deal, austerity could simply power on. She said: When we’ve secured a good Brexit deal for Britain, at the Spending Review next year we will set out our approach for the future.

title: theresa created fantasy world reality
story: NewsopinionTheresa May created a fantasy world in which the reality doesnt match her rhetoricTory austerity was an ideological choice by the Conservatives and communities were kept behind, not left behind, during the past eight grim yearsShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsopinionthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video kevin-maguire-theresa-mays-conference-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May created a fantasy world in which the reality doesnt match her rhetoric. Judge the Dancing Queen by deeds not words and the speech isnt worth the paper its printed on. Tory austerity was an ideological choice by the Conservatives and communities were kept behind, not left behind, during the past eight grim years. And how dishonest of the Prime Minister to pretend the financial fatwas over when benefit cuts alone, including the imposition of Universal Credit, will make poorer lower paid workers in and out of jobs.  Equally the condemnation of horric abuse suffered by Labours Diane Abbott, the countrys first Black woman MP, sounded decent and smart except the Tory Party deliberately target the Shadow Home Secretary.  Where was the apology for Mays racist “Go Home” vans whipping up bigotry  We didnt hear one. Where was the apology for Mays role in the Windrush scandal  We didnt hear one. She and the Tories are clearly spooked by Jeremy Corbyn capturing the zeitgeist for change, people yearning for hope and greater power over their lives. Delivering a better speech than last year was a low bar after the coughing, P and falling letters.  It was about hanging onto her job after Boris Johnsons treachery yet it was noticeable she avoided the C-word: Chequers.

title: baby twins left worst case
story: NewsBaby twins left with worst case of hand, foot and mouth disease after Spanish hotel outbreakMila-Rose and Kyson, from Solihull, West Midlands, became covered in painful and contagious red sores during a family trip to the Club Mac Hotel in AlcudiaShareCommentsByDaniel Bird:,  OCT NewsKimberley McCabe, , with her twins Kysonand Mila-Rose"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum claims her nine-month-old twins were left with the worst case of hand, foot and mouth disease doctors had ever seen after a hushed up outbreak at their Spanish hotel.Disgusted Kimberley McCabe, , from Solihull, West Midlands, alleges twins Mila-Rose and Kyson became covered in painful and contagious red sores during a week-long holiday to the Club Mac Hotel in Alcudia, Majorca, last month.The mum-of-two claims both the hotel and package holiday operator Jet did not warn them about the outbreak before they arrived and instead actively sought to keep it quiet from other guests during their stay.Kimberley alleges she saw multiple guests infected by the virus, which in extreme cases can be fatal, during her first family holiday with the twins.  Club Mac confirmed  people have been confirmed with the infection since September  and said they take health and safety seriously. The hairdresser said: There were no signs warning us of the outbreak during check-in. There was a severe cause of hand, foot and mouth disease spreading, and the staff did their utmost to keep this information quiet. My poor babies were covered in red angry blisters from head to toe, they were so poorly that it completely ruined our holiday. When I approached our Jet rep, they said we dont want to scare our guests, thats why were not telling them. We felt like there was no empathy at all, the hotel just tried to cover it up. As I walked around the resort there were hundreds of cases - I could visibly see the effect it was having on so many other babies and children. When we went to see the hotel doctor, she even said, oh, heres another one! Several other guests had to leave early and ended up in hospital. I dont wish for any family, particularly those with young babies, to have to endure the ordeal we have. There were also many pregnant women at the hotel which is so concerning as the condition can be le threatening for an unborn baby.  Kimberleys claims come after other families have come forward to allege they also have experienced hand, foot and mouth disease symptoms after staying at the hotel.The mum-of-two said she has received hundreds of messages about similar cases since posting about her ordeal on Facebook - some dating back years.The family flew to the Spanish resort on September  and first noticed hand, foot and mouth symptoms in the twins three days later on September . Kimberley said they flew home on September  after being declared fit to fly by the hotel doctor. And Kimberley claims when she took the twins to her GP back in the UK, the doctor told her it was the worst case of the disease they had ever seen. Kimberley also claims the cleanliness of the hotel was not good enough and said after the twins were diagnosed they were banned from the restaurant and pool and told to remain in their room. Hand, foot and mouth the disease is passed on through coughs and sneezes with the NHS stating a person is infectious days before any symptoms become apparent. Kimberley said: The babies were born four weeks premature and have a weakened immune system, so I was so worried about them being ill. Since I posted on Facebook, cases from years ago have been getting in touch with me. We just wish wed been given our right to know. Both our Jet rep and hotel staff lied to our faces - they told us there was a mild case going around and they had only been aware of it for two weeks.  There were no signs throughout the hotel, and we werent advised by staff at check-in or by Jet holidays before arriving. They had a duty of care, but making money was clearly more important to them than the wellbeing of their guests. Its a real shame about the hotel, as its fantastic for children. We feel so let down - both the hotel and Jet have completely failed us and Im disgusted at the way theyve handled it. We still havent had an explanation as to why they deemed it acceptable not to inform guests of this horric outbreak. A spokesperson for Jet said: We are aware of a small number of cases of Hand, Foot and Mouth at the Clu Mac Hotel in Alcudia which, contrary to some reports, first appeared at the hotel in September. Since the appearance of these cases, we have briefed our team on how to spot and prevent the spread of th illness and displayed posters on notice boards in the hotel. We would like to assure our customers that their health and safety is our number one priority, and we work closely with all hotels to ensure that health and safety standards meet the very high requirements that we and our customers expect. Vicente Gim nez, general manager at Club Mac Hotel Alcudia, said: We are aware of a small number of cases of hand-foot-and-mouth at the Club Mac Hotel in Alcudia and were working with our resort teams and customers to do everything possible to reduce the spread of this highly contagious viral infection.

title: driver sending cheeky monkey emoji
story: NewsDriver was sending cheeky monkey emoji messages on her phone when she killed motorist, court hearsGemma Evans, , is accused of using Facebook and WhatsApp to send messages while driving in the dark at mphShareByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  OCT NewsGemma Evans denies causing death by dangerous driving "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA driver was sending cheeky monkey emoji messages on her mobile phone when she killed an innocent motorist, a court heard today. Gemma Evans, , is accused of using Facebook and WhatsApp to send messages while driving in the dark at mph. A jury heard she was grossly distracted causing her black Mini to veer into the path of Diane Price, , who was killed outright. Police seized Evanss mobile phone and found a series of messages allegedly sent while driving.  Prosecutor Thomas Scapens said: Experts have concluded there were no medical or mechanical reasons for Gemma Evans to leave her lane. She did not see the car approaching and did not brake before leaving her lane. We examined her mobile phone and found she was using it up to the point of collision. Evans was driving to work at .am on Friday  December  while Mrs Price was coming the other way after spending the night caring for her elderly father. The court heard Evanss Mini suddenly veered across the road on a straight stretch of the A, near Brecon, Powys. Other motorists and paramedics gave CPR but Ms Price died of catastrophic injuries at the scene. The jury was given a print-out of Evanss mobile phone activity in the minutes before the crash near the village of Llanspyddyd.  It showed she exchanged messages with friend Kirsty Arrowsmith making arrangements for a girls night out and signed off with cheeky monkey and thumbs up emojis. Mr Scapens said: The first message from Miss Arrowsmith at .am said: Hey you, drinking tonight or having a quiet one  Miss Evans replied with four heart emojis saying: Overslept along with a cheeky monkey face and three kisses. Merthyr Tydfil Crown Court heard the two friends swapped messages about what they were going to wear on the night out.

title: first known moon beyond solar
story: NewsFirst known moon beyond solar system discovered , light years awayMeasuring around the same size as Nepture, it is  times bigger than our own satelliteShareCommentsByMark Waghorn:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAn artists impression of the exoplanet Kepler b, transiting the star "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe first known moon beyond the Solar System has been discovered by astronomers. Roughly the size of Neptune, it is  times bigger than our own satellite - and is some , light years away. To date there are more than , exoplanets - worlds orbiting stars other than the Sun - but no exomoons. Dr David Kipping, an Assistant Professor at Columbia University in New York, said: This would be the first case of detecting a moon outside our solar system.  If confirmed by follow-up Hubble observations, the finding could provide vital clues about the development of planetary systems and may cause experts to revisit theories of how moons form around planets. The hunt for exomoons - which are just as likely to harbour le - has run parallel to that for moons. But these extrasolar satellites had lingered at the limits of detection with current techniques. Columbia colleague Alex Teachey say they now have compelling evidence for one - thanks to its large size. They believe its orbiting a gas giant. Almost  moons have been identied in our own star system - and none are anywhere near as gargantuan. Using the Kepler space telescope the researchers analysed data from  exoplanets which had wide orbits - periods greater than  days - around their host star.  The observations measured the momentary dimming of starlight as a planet passed in front of its star - called a transit. One planet called Kepler b had intriguing anomalies. Dr Kipping explained: We saw little deviations and wobbles in the light curve that caught our attention. The results were enough for the team to get  hours of time with NASAs Hubble to intensively study the planet - supplying them with data four times more precise. They monitored the planet before and during its -hour-long transit across the face of the star. After it ended the telescope detected a second and much smaller decrease in the stars brightness three-and-a-half hours later. Dr Kipping said this was consistent with a moon trailing the planet like a dog following its owner on a leash. He said: Unfortunately, the scheduled Hubble observations ended before the complete transit of the moon could be measured. The study, published in the journal Science Advances, also provided supporting evidence for the moon by discovering the planet began its transit  minutes earlier than predicted.  This suggested both it and the moon were orbiting a common centre of gravity - known in astronomy as the barycentre - that would cause the planet to wobble from its expected location. Dr Kipping said: An extraterrestrial civilisation watching the Earth and Moon transit the Sun would note similar anomalies in the timing of Earths transit. In principle this anomaly could be caused by the gravitational pull of a hypothetical second planet in the system. But Kepler found no evidence for additional planets around the star during its four-year mission, said the researchers. Lead author Mr Teachey, a graduate fellow in astronomy, said: A companion moon is the simplest and most natural explanation for the second dip in the light curve and the orbit-timing deviation. It was a shocking moment to see that light curve - my heart started beating a little faster and I just kept looking at that signature. story: NewsMum tells how daughter,, was swept to her death by "freak ft wave" as they walked along the beachRose Carter, from Salisbury, Wiltshire, was on a family walk at Durdle Door, Dorset when the youngster was struck by an eight-foot waveShareCommentsByBen Mitchell:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAn inquest has found the death was a tragic accident"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A distraught mother has described to an inquest the moment her five-year-old daughter was swept out to sea by a freak wave while walking at the Durdle Door beauty spot.Rose Carter, from Salisbury, Wiltshire, was with her sister and her mother, Sofia Carter, at the Dorset beach on April  when the youngster was hit by the ft wave. The Coastguard was alerted and a military vessel helped rescue her, but she was pronounced dead at Dorset County Hospital in Dorchester. Mrs Carter, who did not attend the Bournemouth hearing, said in a statement that the sea was rough but she did not think it was dangerous as they walked along the edge of the beach with Rose about ft behind her.  She said: I saw a really big wave that went over her head and knocked her off her feet. Mrs Carter said a second wave then also knocked her into the water and she added: When I stood up I could no longer see Rose. Rose was beyond the breaking waves and I was aware a lady called  and a military boat was there within minutes. A man with binoculars directed the boat to where Rose was. Rose was taken from the sea. Another witness, Gordon Cobb, said he heard Mrs Carter screaming: My daughter, my girl or my baby, and added: I could see a little girls head sticking out of the wave, physically there was no way she could have got through the wave. story: News"Perfectionist" teacher, , upset at being branded emotionally immature by therapist found hanged"Talented" Chy Peart, , was discovered by her firefighter husband Mark but despite his efforts at CPR she sadly diedShareByMark Lister:,  OCT NewsChy Peart was praised as a talented teacher by colleagues "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA perfectionist teacher branded emotionally immature by an occupational therapist was found hanged at her home, an inquest heard. Chy was pronounced dead by paramedics at the couple’s home, in Rotherham, South Yorks, on April . In a statement, read at Doncaster Coroner’s Court by coroners officer David Copley, Mr Peart said he had been working a day sht at Manvers Fire Station. I arrived home at about .pm and the house was in darkness, he said. “I discovered Chy hanging. The inquest heard how Chy, who taught at Rawmarsh Community School and also ran a textiles business, was signed off work by her GP Dr Biing Hen on a number of occasions dating back to November .  Helen O’Brien, headteacher at Rawmarsh Community School, described Chy as a ‘positive role model for students’ and a ‘very, very talented textiles teacher’. Mrs O’Brien took Chy to the hospital on November , last year, after she told another member of staff she’d had suicidal thoughts on the journey to work. The court also heard she attempted to take her le in February, information which was not shared with the school. In March, Dr Hen said Chy became ‘annoyed’ by a letter from an occupational therapist which labelled her as ‘emotionally immature’, something her mother, who was present in court, said ‘changed her completely’. Mrs O’Brien said: “Chy disagreed and contested with the occupational health report. I said I would speak to her GP to get a second opinion. “The door was kept open – at no point was Chy told she wouldn’t be able toto school.”  The court also heard Chy had ‘hopes of having a child’ but that she had told a mental health worker that she felt like she was stuck in a hamster wheel of everything’. Assistant coroner for Doncaster, Louise Slater questioned the use of the phrase ‘emotionally immature’ and said it was not a ‘medical diagnosis’. Recording a narrative verdict, Mrs Slater said she could not record a conclusion of suicide as she said the evidence she had heard did not prove Chy intended to take her own le. “Chy was a good teacher,” said Mrs Slater. “She was liked and respected by her peers, certainly the management and , although not here, I suspect the pupils as well and probably their parents. ”But it would appear from the evidence that Chy found it dficult to accept that she was actually quite good at what she did. “She was always striving to be better and perhaps she was a bit of a perfectionist.”

They believe this may have had some impact on the baby’s facial deformation. Matthew was born via cesarean section in a hospital in Santiago town in northern Philippines.  He said: When I first saw our baby, I trembled, felt weak and almost collapsed inside the delivery room. He was almost faceless. The next day, despite his condition, baby Matthew was discharged while Isabela was left at the intensive care unit for two weeks. Isabela continues to feed him drops of milk and vitamins for him to stay healthy and he is now celebrating his first birthday on October . Meanwhile Raven is working at a clothes factory in Balintawak, Quezon City earning  per day, around poundper month, which is barely enough for the family to survive. Despite the family’s below minimum wage income, support from relatives and the public help them afford daily basic needs for Matthews survival.

story: NewsToddler spotted alone outside shop sparks outrage among parentsThe young girl was pictured sitting in a ride-on car outside a charity shop in east HullShareCommentsByJoanna LovellKelly-Ann Mills:,  OCT NewsThe image shows an abandoned toddler in east Hull "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA photograph appearing to show a toddler left on her own outside a shop has sparked outrage among parents. The young girl was pictured sitting in a ride-on car outside a charity shop in east Hull. In the snap, she can be seen looking into the window of the shop with no adults in sight.It was posted in the Hull Crime Watch Facebook page after being taken on Wednesday, and has been commented on hundreds of times. The woman who took the picture said she was so concerned she reported it to Humberside Police and was told officers will patrol the area. She said: We were in the car at the traffic lights waiting until they changed. People came out the shop and the child was just sat there. The little girl tried to lean to open the door at one point. People was just walking past her as well, but she looked about two -that. Since posting it people have said they have seen her on her own before so the police said they will patrol the area and check CCTV. Many parents shared the same concerns and said a child that young should never be left alone. But others pointed out that years ago it was the norm. Katherine Ness said: What a joke. Shouldnt be allowed kids. Rachael Jackson said: You just wouldn’t risk it! Bet she wouldn’t park her car outside with the keys left in the ignition! And personally I’d rather do that then leave my child outside, just my opinion but think the authority’s would probably have something to say too.  Debbie Goldsmith said: Going back  yrs plus people use to leave prams outside shops and never give it a second thought show you how society as changed. Chloe Dyson said: You all go on about good old days, rah rah rah. Its wrong, theres a big main road next to the shop too. Shouldnt have kidsyou cant look after them. You leave a dog out side shop not a child absolutely disgusting behaviour. Elkie Shehan said: I wouldnt leave a dog outside a shop let alone a child. Lucy Eckles said: Its still a young toddler. As a parent Id judge them too as clearly incapable and untrusted with kids. Whoever took the photo could of clearly done much worsethey wanted to since no one was looking after the child.

title: did you know 80000 people visit dundee botanic garden every year
story: The Botanic Garden of the University of Dundee is one of the city’s major attractions, welcoming more than , visitors each year, writes Garry Fraser in The Scots Magazine.South-facing and situated in the West End of the city, you can enjoy a pleasant wander amongst acres of beautul coners, trees and shrubs.“The garden hosts a first-class collection of trees from all around the world,” says the garden’s education officer Doctor Neil Paterson.“Giant redwoods, coastal redwoods and Australian eucalyptus trees, complete with their aromatic smell.#We even have our own version of the Scots pine-dominated Great Caledonian Forest plus monkey puzzles from seeds collected in Chile.“Traditionally, botanic gardens weren’t interested in native species, but we bucked the trend by concentrating on them from the start. However, species from around the world were also included so both grew together.”The trees form an integral part of the garden’s round-the-world tour, where you can move from the Mediterranean area to the Australian and New Zealand section via America and Asia.“My favourite part is our uniquely large native plants area which features eight Tayside habitats,” continues Neil.“You can walk from the glens to the sea taking in heathland, oakwood, the Great Caledonian Forest, nutrient-rich lochs and sand dunes.“The huge glasshouse that stands prominently at the entrance to the garden is a tour all to itself, dominated by the contrasting tropical rainforest – mahogany, ebony, teak and the plants that climb on or live on trees – and plants that thrive in hot desert habitats.These include cacti from America and euphorbias from Africa. The Glasshouse pond features the Giant Victoria Water Lily.“Throughout the garden and glasshouses there is a Plants for People Trail which highlights plants that humans have used for everything from food, construction and medicine to sewage treatment,” adds Neil.

title: give laurie ellis the managers job permanently says dundee united legend john holt
story: Tangerine legend John Holt believes the Dundee United board do not have to leave Tannadice to find the perfect successor to Csaba Laszlo.The man who won the Premier League and two League Cups with United believes caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is the man to take over on a permanent basis.John remains a regular at home matches through his work in the Tannadice hospitality lounges and was sad to see Csaba sacked but believes after a dficult start to the season that the - weekend loss to Ross County made his departure inevitable.“You never like to see a manager sacked and I feel sorry for Csaba, I really do, but it’s been clear for a while now things haven’t been working.“Saturday was another bad home defeat and, for any manager,the team isn’t performing in front of their own fans it’s a big problem.“After the fourth goal I’d say between , and , fans just got up and left. You can’t have that. I know United are not where they want to be right now but even so you can’t have that kind of defeat at a club this size.”“Holtie” was pleased to see Ellis put in interim charge after the manager was sacked on Sunday but feels the way forward was a permanent appointment there and then.“I’ve spoken to Laurie a few times now and he comes across as someone who knows what he’s talking about and how to get the best out of players.“That’s what United need right now because they’ve a decent squad, it’s just that Csaba wasn’t getting the best out of them.“Laurie’s still young and it would be his first job as a manager, but with an experienced No  I think he’d be a success.“He’s got a steely edge to him but he gets along with people. He’d be good with you boys in the press and unlike in my day that’s important for a manager.”If Ellis doesn’t get the nod, the former favourite knows who he’d like to see the club turn to but accepts his second choice may not be heading back to Scotland any time soon.“Billy McKinlay is someone who’d do a great job. ‘Badger’ is a respected coach and he’s someone who knows his stuff.“I think the problem with him would be the level he’s been operating at down in England and where.”

title: jim mcinally backs former dundee united teammate to take over as manager
story: Jim McInally believes a former team mate would be the best choice as Dundee United’s new manager.The Tangerines are searching for a replacement for Csaba Lazlo.But Tannadice legend McInally would plump for Billy McKinlay, who made  appearances for United and has worked as a coach with Roy Hodgson at Fulham and David Moyes at Real Sociedad, Sunderland and West Ham.McInally, now Peterhead boss, told the Evening Express: “There are problems in boardrooms with chairman and directors who don’t look at the bigger picture enough.“Billy McKinlay had one failed spell as a manager in Norway.“But ultimately he’s worked at the highest level with Real Sociedad, Fulham under Roy Hodgson and last season at West Ham, and David Moyes thinks the world of him.#What I know about Billy is that he’s a really good organiser of a team and from what I understand that’s what United need.“It’s not just because he’s an old team-mate but he’s somebody that’s dferent and I would like to see the people making the decision look at the bigger picture.”McInally, who played  times for United, is desperate to see his old clubto the Premiership.He added: “Their current plight has been down to lack of leadership at the top.#

title: no looking back now for dundee after win nabi
story: There’s no looking back now for Dundee after they picked up their first victory of the season at the weekend, according to attacker Adil Nabi.The - success at the Hope CBD Stadium in Hamilton brought a welcome end to their run of seven-straight league defeats which stretched back all the way to last season.And, now they have got up and running finally, Nabi says it’s onwards and upwards for his new side.And he’s targeting a second result on the bounce when Kilmarnock come to Dens this coming Saturday.He said: “We’re not looking back – it’s all about looking forward now as a team and it’s about kicking on.“Bring on Saturday back at home.“We didn’t really look at the table but we knew the situation, you can’t hide away from that but as a team we have shown what we are like and we’re going to keep going and going.“On our day we can beat anyone, we’re not scared of anyone.“When we play like we played at Hamilton, showing both sides of the game, we can beat anyone.”The former West Brom and Peterborough forward, who signed for the Dark Blues in the summer, admits they had a bit of luck on their side against Accies.However, he insists that was deserved after a performance that showed two sides to Dundee’s current side.“It was overdue,” he added.“We rode our luck and got some luck back on Saturday – they hit the bar twice but we showed we can play our football and we can fight as well.“We showed that in abundance on Saturday.“Everyone is over the moon, the gaffer, the boys, absolutely buzzing and cant wait for the next game.“If you’re going to win sometimes you have to ride the storm and we rode it quite well.“There was no doubting they would come at us and put us under the cosh. We were troubled a few times but that was it, really.“We played as a team and that’s what we are about, to be honest.“We can play football but we know how to change it up sometimes, we can play long or play short and we showed that on Saturday.”Nabi has had to be patient in his short Dundee career so far after impressing during the club’s pre-season training trip to Portugal and earning a six-month deal.Saturday was just his fth start for the club and he says he’s starting to feel he’s up to speed.And he has promised to repay a lot of online support from Dundee fans by beginning to hit the net.Nabi had the chance to open his account against Hamilton but sent a good opportunity over the bar.He added: “I said to the gaffer that after my third, fourth start I’d be firing.“I’m slowly showing that, getting chances and looking lively.“I know the fans are happy with me – I read on the internet all the time that they are buzzing!“Hopefully, now I can start getting myself on the scoresheet and carry on.“I should have put that one away definitely but that’s going to come, I know that for sure.“My goals will come.”And with the club finally heading in the right direction, Nabi expects to have more opportunities to score as the team’s fortunes improve.“The win changes the mindset for us. As a team, when we were losing, we didn’t really let that get to us.“I know we’ve been under pressure having not won but as a team we’ve been positive.“We always knew we wanted to get that goal first and we showed what we can do when we get in front. There’s no better feeling than coming away with the three points and long may it continue.“Our season starts now and whatever happened before is past and we need to kick on.”

title: paul quinn claims paul sturrocks role undermined csaba laszlo at dundee united
story: Former Dundee United defender Paul Quinn believes there have to be major changes at the clubthey are to progress.A policy was introduced in the summer to ensure new signings live within a -mile radius of the city but Quinn felt that was papering over the cracks.He said: “Dundee United fans have proved themselves to be good, loyal supporters over the years. They want the best for their club but when you are in Dundee getting moaned at from fans, I guess in restaurants etc, that’s not helpful to the players.“What they should try and change is Tannadice.“When you go in the door it needs modernised.“I love all their history. There are players there up on the wall who I couldn’t even begin to lace their boots. Even within the tunnel area, though, could there not be something changed to reflect the modern era “Something needs to change in the mental side of things to move Dundee United forward.”Quinn was surprised to see club legend Paul Sturrockto Tannadice in March as an adviser to Csaba Laszlo. He said: “Our manager is our leader – that’s the golden rule in football.“You give the gaffer everything but then somebody  comes in all of a sudden and immediately you think: ‘What’s going on here ’“Players talk as football is a small world. They think: ‘The manager likes me but do I now need to keep this new guy happy as well ’“I felt for Csaba then. There’s no way you can dispute what Luggy did as a player for United but that was back in the day.“It looked from the outside as though there was undermining going on – that’s just a fact.”

title: piers morgan turns up in local area when he was due to be presenting good morning britain
story: Piers Morgan was expected to present Good Morning Britain this morning # instead he turned up in the local area.The TV celebrity is the controversial presenter of ITV#s flagship breakfast show on the first three days of the week.But this morning his co-host Susanna Reid told viewers he was #off for a few days#, with Ben Shephard stepping in at the last minute.mdash Piers MorganOctober , Shephard told viewers he was asked to step in and joked: #I had a phone call saying they#ve had enough, he#s off, he#s out.#The truth, however, is that Morgan was in St Andrews to play in the Alfred Dunhill Links Championship.Morgan posted a picture on his Instagram account with Ryder Cup hero Tommy Fleetwood at St Andrews. title: relieved gaffer neil hopes hamilton win is turning point for dundee
story: Dundee boss Neil McCann says he hopes his side have turned the corner on their season after being “well worth the three points” at Hamilton.The Dark Blues earned their first Premiership victory of the season with a - success at the Hope CBD Stadium with goals at the end of each half from defender Andy Boyle and midfielder Kharl Madianga.Heading into the contest, the Dens men had no points to their name after six matches but have cut the gap to the teams above them with St Mirren and Motherwell now just a point ahead in th and th position respectively.Dundee gaffer Neil was delighted to finally get off the mark and is hoping it’s just a belated start to the season for his side.He said: “I hope this is the turning point. I just felt we needed to get the first win and I believe in them to go on now.“We enjoyed the weekend because it had been a long time coming.“It’s a relief to get the three points, I’m not going to lie but I’m really pleased for the guys because I’ve been talking for weeks about the belief I still have in them that they could get a result.“I thought we were well worth the three points.“I thought we absolutely dominated the first half, we didn’t change how we played – there’s no use in me saying I have belief in them and then changing how we play.“I thought it was the right way to go on Saturday and we dominated the ball, created chances and it was a great header from Boyle.”On more than one occasion this season Dundee have had the better of the overall play but were unable to take advantage by grabbing the lead.This time, though, with Preston loanee Boyle’s th minute header they did just that and, after seeing Accies pass up a number of chances, sealed victory in stoppage time as Madianga smashed the ball beyond Gary Woods to send the fans and the bench delirious.Neil added: “It was sheer joy. Football is about winning games and when you’re down sometimes you don’t get a lot of luck but we got a bit of luck on Saturday.“I’ve been hammering to them about getting into the lead but we’ve been conceding goals quickly and that belief that you can win games clearly reduces.“I just said to them that our gameplan is to get into the lead, not to just sit back and try to recover from - down.“However, only they can make that happen. Hamilton will have said, ‘get a goal against them and they’re dead’ but the players were well fired up on Saturday, I didn’t have to do anything.“When the goal goes in from Boyle, great delivery from Calvin Miller, you know you have something tangible to hang on to.“I’m so pleased, I don’t want to go overboard because it is only three points but it is a big three points for the club.”

title: these were csaba laszlos last words as dundee united boss
story: Deep inside the bowels of Tannadice was where Csaba Laszlo carried out one of his last acts as Dundee United manager, speaking to the press after his team hit self destruct in losing - to Ross County on Saturday.Csaba was quizzed on where it all went wrong for him, not just on the day, but over the course of his near year-long reign as the sense he was a dead man walking filled the air.He was down and seemed defeated when laying out his defence and it was clear it was going to be the last time he spoke as the manager of Dundee United Football Club.Askedhe had considered resigning, he said: “I don’t think resigning is an option but it was a terrible result.“The team know that and we have to take the responsibility for it.“It wasn’t just one or two people # it’s the full team who have to take the responsibility.“I don’t think we are so bad going by results but we lost five goals at home.“Especially being so positive after the Falkirk game, we were % going into this dficult run.“We knew it wasn’t going to be easy but we showed real confidence and the injured players have slowly been coming back.“We wanted to avoid a result like Saturday – it’s not what we wished for.”Csaba did confirm that, as ever, he would speak with chairman Mike Martin which ultimately led to him being sacked on Sunday afternoon.The Hungarian also conceded he and the players had let the fans down with the display and recent struggles.He added: “I believe in my players and they feel the same after losing the game.“They don’t want to push the responsibility away – it’s not that easy. Saturday there was no evidence that we’re a good team.“The players let themselves down, too, not just me. We brought these players in to try to get promotion back to the Premiership.“Everybody is responsible after this defeat. It’s not easy to find clear words for it.“I don’t expect the fans to be happy after this defeat.”And Csaba’s sense that things were coming to a close were evident in the following comment.He admitted: “This is the worst I’ve felt as the manager of Dundee United, especially at home.“We didn’t have to concede those goals but I don’t want to point fingers at anybody. Everybody knows it was a bad performance.”

title: two names stand out as folk interested in dundee united managers job reaches double figures
story: Two names stand out from the rest of the candidates to lead Dundee United on a permanent basis.The Tele revealed yesterday that caretaker boss Laurie Ellis is to be given the chance to show he’s the man to succeed Csaba Laszlo, who was sacked after Saturday#s - Tannadice drubbing by Ross County.However, should the board choose to make an external appointment ex-United pair Robbie Neilson and Jim McIntyre would be top of their list.The Tele understands expressions of interest in the post are already running well into double figures and that includes managers in employment.While the Tannadice board will consider all serious applications, however, they are believed to be keen to give caretaker boss Laurie Ellis the opportunity to prove his worth.This will be his second spell as caretaker boss. Last year he had two games in the hotseat after Ray McKinnon was sacked and led the team back to the top of the ision via impressive victories over eventual champions St Mirren and away to Dumbarton.At the time that prompted the board to urge him to apply for the job permanently but Ellis felt he lacked the experience to take on a club of United’s size.A year on that view might have changed and, was he to succeed Csaba, he would be a popular appointment in the dressing-room.The fact he’s a leading contender is further indication of how highly he is rated by his employers. While it was hoped Csaba would be the man to lead the team back to the Premiership, for some time now the former Raith Rovers stalwart has been viewed by many within Tannadice as a future boss.That said he does face competition from others with more experience and both Neilson and McIntyre will be interested.The pair could need convincing the Tangerines can succeed.Although he’s been out of a job since ending a dficult spell in England with MK Dons in January, Neilson’s stock north of the border remains high.As head coach of Hearts for two years from , he guided the Tynecastle outfit to promotion from a Championship that included hot favourites Rangers and Edinburgh rivals Hibs.On a tight budget, he then steered them to a top-six finish and Europa League qualication in their first season back in the Premiership.McIntyre has considerable experience from his time in charge at Dunfermline, Queen of the South and Ross County, where he lted the League Cup.He’s been out of a job since being sacked by the Staggies in September last year.While it’s known both are keen to get back in management, they’ll onlyin the right circumstances.In August, McIntyre turned down the offer to succeed Paul Hartley at Falkirk. He felt the budget there would not be sufficient to mount a promotion challenge.Likewise, earlier in the summer the vacant post at St Mirren was there for the taking for Neilson.After talks with the board, the -year-old decided their expectations were unrealistic and the job wasn’t for him.
